Laura Gibbs · 38. The Story of Karna and the Two Curses
A charioteer had found baby Karna in the river and adopted him, but Karna's life was cursed.First, practicing archery, Karna accidentally killed a brahmin's cow. "You will die like my cow," swore the brahmin, "struck down by an inescapable arrow."Another time, Karna saw a girl crying because she had spilled a pot of milk. Feeling sorry for her, Karna squeezed the milk back out of the earth. This caused the earth great pain, and the earth goddess, Bhudevi, cursed Karna. "When you are in danger," she said, "I will not help you; instead, I will help your opponent."
Inspired by: The Mahabharata: A Shortened Modern Prose Version by R. K. Narayan
Notes: This story is from Chapter 16: Victory and Sorrow. Narayan includes the story of the brahmin and the cow, but not the story about Bhudevi.Bhudevi

content.text: In a peaceful village nestled by the river, a charioteer named Ravi stumbled upon a baby boy floating in a basket. The child's eyes sparkled with innocence, and Ravi's heart melted at the sight. Without hesitation, he scooped up the baby and decided to adopt him as his own.

As the years passed, the boy named Karna grew up under Ravi's loving care. He possessed a natural talent for archery, spending countless hours honing his skills. One fateful day, while practicing his aim, tragedy struck. Karna's arrow veered off course and struck a cow belonging to a respected Brahmin.

The Brahmin, filled with rage and grief, approached Karna with fury in his eyes. "You have taken the life of my beloved cow," he seethed. "For this, you shall meet the same fate. An inescapable arrow will find you, and death shall be your companion."

Karna's heart sank as he realized the gravity of his mistake. He pleaded for forgiveness, but the Brahmin's curse remained steadfast. From that moment on, Karna knew that his life would forever be shadowed by the curse of the Brahmin.

In another incident, Karna came across a young girl sobbing uncontrollably. She had accidentally spilled a pot of milk, and her tears flowed like a river. Touched by her distress, Karna's compassionate nature compelled him to help. With a gentle touch, he pressed his hands against the ground, and miraculously, the milk flowed back into the pot.

Little did Karna know that his act of kindness would bring about another curse upon his life. The earth goddess, Bhudevi, felt the pain of her soil being squeezed, and her anger consumed her. She appeared before Karna, her voice filled with wrath.
"You have caused me great agony," Bhudevi declared. "For your thoughtless actions, I curse you. In times of peril, I shall not come to your aid. Instead, I will lend my support to your adversaries."

Karna's heart sank even further, burdened by the weight of these two curses. He knew that his path in life would be fraught with challenges and hardships. Yet, he remained determined to face them head-on, for he believed that his destiny was not solely defined by these curses.

And so, Karna embarked on a journey, his chariot carrying him across vast lands and into the heart of battles. With each passing day, he encountered numerous trials, but his spirit remained unyielding. He knew that he had the power to rise above his cursed fate and prove his worth.

As Karna's story unfolded, his name echoed through the ages, inspiring generations to come. His unwavering loyalty, unmatched valor, and unbreakable spirit became the stuff of legends. Despite the curses that plagued his life, Karna's legacy shone brightly, reminding us all that even in the face of adversity, true strength lies within the depths of our hearts.
